pygraphc.clustering.ClusterDistance module¶

class ClusterDistance[source]¶

Bases: object

Class for distance measurement between two vertices.

static get_cosine_similarity(tfidf1, tfidf2, length1, length2)[source]¶

Measure cosine similarity between two strings.

Typically, it is similarity between two event log messages in the two vertices in graph-based event log clustering.

Parameters:
  • tfidf1 (list) – List of tf-idf measure from the first message.
  • tfidf2 (list) – List of tf-idf measure from the second message.
  • length1 (float) – Denominator in cosine similarity from the first message.
  • length2 (float) – Denominator in cosine similarity from the second message.
Returns:

cosine_similarity – Cosine similarity between two strings.
Return type:

float

static get_geometric_mean(weights)[source]¶

Get geometric mean or intensity in a clique. A clique can be a k-clique or maximal clique.

Parameters:weights (list[float]) – List of edge weight in a clique.
Returns:gmean – Geometric mean of given edge weights.
Return type:float
static get_weighted_cliques(graph, cliques, threshold)[source]¶

Get weighted cliques based on given intensity threshold.

A clique which its weight are less then threshold is omiited. This procedure will filter unsignificant cliques.

Parameters:
  • graph (graph) – A graph to check for its weighted cliques.
  • cliques (list[frozenset]) – List of clique list found.
  • threshold (float) – Intensity (geometric mean) threshold.
Returns:

weighted_cliques – List of clique with significant weight.
Return type:

list[list]

Parameters:
  • graph (graph) – Graph to be set for its cluster id.
  • clusters (dict[list]) – Dictionary contains list of node in a particular cluster.

pygraphc.clustering.ConnectedComponents module¶

class ConnectedComponents(graph)[source]¶

This is a class for connected component detection method to cluster event logs [Studiawan2016a].

References

[Studiawan2016a]H. Studiawan, B. A. Pratomo, and R. Anggoro, Connected component detection for authentication log clustering, The 2nd International Seminar on Science and Technology, pp. 495-496, 2016.
get_clusters()[source]¶

This method find any connected component in a graph.

A component represents a cluster and each component will be given a cluster identifier. This method heavily rely on the cosine similarity threshold to build an edge in a graph.

Returns:clusters – Dictionary of cluster list, where each list contains index (line number) of event log.
Return type:dict[list]

pygraphc.clustering.GraphEntropy module¶

class GraphEntropy(graph)[source]¶

Bases: object

A class for graph clustering using entropy-based method [Kenley2011]. The review of
some graph clustering method for PPI networks, including this entropy-based, was presented in [Price2013]. This code is NetworkX version of the original code by True Price [Price2016].

References

[Kenley2011]Edward Casey Kenley and Young-Rae Cho, Detecting protein complexes and functional modules from protein interaction networks: A graph entropy approach, Proteomics 2011, 11, pp. 3835-3844.
[Price2013]True Price, Francisco I Pena III, Young-Rae Cho, Survey: Enhancing Protein Complex Prediction in PPI Networks with GO Similarity Weighting, Interdisciplinary Sciences: Computational Life Sciences, 5(3), pp. 196-210, 2013.
[Price2016]True Price, Graph clustering in Python, https://github.com/trueprice/python-graph-clustering.
_get_entropies(cluster_candidate, neighbors)[source]¶

Get entropy from cluster candidate or all nodes in a graph.

Parameters:
  • cluster_candidate (iterable) – The entity to be analyzed for its entropy. It can be cluster candidate or a graph.
  • neighbors (list) – The neigbors of processed node.
Returns:

entropies – Dictionary of entropies. Key: node identifier and value: entropy.
Return type:

dict

Get node’s entropy.

Parameters:
  • cluster_candidate (set) – The entity to be analyzed for its entropy. It can be cluster candidate or a graph.
  • node (int) – The analyzed node to be calculated for its entropy.
Returns:

entropy – Entropy for a particular node.
Return type:

pygraphc.clustering.KCliquePercolation module¶

class KCliquePercolation(graph, edges_weight, nodes_id, k)[source]¶

Bases: object

This is a class for graph clustering based on k-clique percolation [Farkas2007].

The procedure will find k-clique. If there is any percolation between k-cliques, it will be set as a cluster. The unnecessary edges will be removed. The use of this method for event log clustering was presented in [Studiawan2016b].

References

[Farkas2007]I. J. Farkas, D. Abel, G. Palla, and T. Vicsek, Weighted network modules, New Journal of Physics, 9(6), p. 180, 2007.
[Studiawan2016b]H. Studiawan, B. A. Pratomo, and R. Anggoro, Clustering of SSH brute-force attack logs using k-clique percolation, in Proceedings of the 10th International Conference on Information Communication Technology and Systems, pp. 33-36, 2016.
_build_temp_graph()[source]¶

Build a temporary graph to get a percolation between individual k-clique.

_enumerate_all_cliques()[source]¶

Returns all cliques in an undirected graph.

This method returns cliques of size (cardinality) k = 1, 2, 3, ..., maxDegree - 1. Where maxDegree is the maximal degree of any node in the graph.

Returns:generator of lists
Return type:generator of list for each clique.

Notes

Based on the algorithm published by Zhang et al. (2005) [Zhang2005] and adapted to output all cliques discovered. This algorithm is not applicable on directed graphs. This algorithm ignores self-loops and parallel edges as clique is not conventionally defined with such edges. There are often many cliques in graphs. This algorithm however, hopefully, does not run out of memory since it only keeps candidate sublists in memory and continuously removes exhausted sublists.

The original source code is taken from NetworkX development branch [Schult2016].

References

[Zhang2005]Yun Zhang, Abu-Khzam, F.N., Baldwin, N.E., Chesler, E.J., Langston, M.A., Samatova, N.F., Genome-Scale Computational Approaches to Memory-Intensive Applications in Systems Biology. Supercomputing, 2005. Proceedings of the ACM/IEEE SC 2005 Conference, pp. 12, 12-18 Nov. 2005. doi: 10.1109/SC.2005.29. http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?tp=&arnumber=1559964&isnumber=33129
[Schult2016]Dan Schult, Source code for networkx.algorithms.clique. https://networkx.github.io/documentation/development/_modules/networkx/algorithms/clique.html
_find_kcliques()[source]¶

Find all k-cliques in a graph.

Returns:kcliques – List of k-cliques found but only return specified k. The frozenset contains nodes identifier.
Return type:list[frozenset]
_get_clusters()[source]¶

Get final result of the k-clique percolation clustering.

Returns:clusters – Dictionary of list containing nodes identifier for each cluster.
Return type:dict[list]
_get_percolation_graph(kcliques)[source]¶

Get percolation graph.

This temporary graph also well known as percolation graph in the literatures. A node represents a k-clique and an edge will be drawn if there is any intersection between two k-cliques.

Parameters:kcliques (list[frozenset]) – List of all k-cliques found with user-specified k.
_remove_outcluster()[source]¶

Remove edges that connect to other clusters.

This method will first find any edges in the cluster member. If edges connecting to a node does not belong to the current cluster, then it will be removed.

get_clique_percolation()[source]¶

Get all cluster in percolation (temporary) graph.

Returns:clique_percolation – Dictionary of nodes in each cluster in frozenset.
Return type:dict[frozenset]
get_kclique_percolation()[source]¶

This is the main method to call all k-clique percolation clustering.

Returns:clusters – List of list containing nodes identifier for each cluster.
Return type:dict[list]
get_percolation_nodes()[source]¶

Get percolation nodes after finished clustering.

Returns:percolated_nodes – List of all percolated nodes
Return type:list
get_removed_edges()[source]¶

Returns:removed_edges – List of tuple containing edge from (node1, node2)
Return type:list[tuple]
class KCliquePercolationWeighted(graph, edges_weight, nodes_id, k, threshold)[source]¶

Bases: pygraphc.clustering.KCliquePercolation.KCliquePercolation

This a class derived from KCliquePercolation for the case of weighted graph.

_find_kcliques()[source]¶

This method will find weighted k-clique.

The weight of k-clique is calculated based on the geometric mean of its weights.

Returns:weighted_kcliques – List of frozenset containing nodes identifier for each k-clique found.
Return type:list[frozenset]

pygraphc.clustering.MajorClust module¶

class ImprovedMajorClust(graph)[source]¶

Bases: pygraphc.clustering.MajorClust.MajorClust

A class that improves MajorClust.

It improves the method _re_majorclust to have re-evaluation. This procedure then add refine cluster step as the re-majorclust provides overvitting clusters.

_backto_prerefine()[source]¶

This procedure will convert the result of clustering from refined graph to original graph.

_re_majorclust(node, graph)[source]¶

Re-evaluation of a node after clustered by standard MajorClust.

Parameters:
  • node (node) – An evaluated node.
  • graph (graph) – A graph to be clustered. It can be original graph or the refined one.
_refine_cluster()[source]¶

Refine cluster by representing a previously generated cluster as a vertex.

Returns:refined_nodes – List of list containing node identifier and its properties.
Return type:list[list]
get_improved_majorclust()[source]¶

The main method to run improved MajorClust algorithm. The procedure gets the refined nodes and call ImprovedMajorClust once again.

Returns:clusters – Dictionary of list containing node identifier for each cluster.
Return type:dict[list]

Bases: object

The implementation of MajorClust graph clustering algorithm [Stein1999].

[Stein1999]B. Stein and O. Niggemann, On the nature of structure and its identification, Proceedings of the 25th International Workshop on Graph-Theoretic Concepts in Computer Science, pp. 122-134, 1999.

_majorclust(graph)[source]¶

The main procedure of MajorClust which is visiting every node to be evaluated for its neighbor cluster.

Parameters:graph (graph) – A graph to be clustered. It can be original graph or the refined one.

Evaluating the neighbor nodes.

pygraphc.clustering.MaxCliquesPercolation module¶

class MaxCliquesPercolation(graph, edges_weight, nodes_id, k)[source]¶

Bases: pygraphc.clustering.KCliquePercolation.KCliquePercolation

This class find maximal cliques and their percolation in a graph.

The procedure will find any intersection (percolation) between any maximal cliques found. The cluster is defined as percolated maximal cliques [Reid2012].

References

[Reid2012]Fergal Reid, Aaron McDaid, and Neil Hurley. Percolation computation in complex networks. In Proceedings of the 2012 IEEE/ACM International Conference on Advances in Social Networks Analysis and Mining, pp. 274-281, 2012.
_find_maxcliques()[source]¶

Find maximal cliques using find_clique function from NetworkX.

Returns:maxcliques – List of frozenset containing node id for each maximal clique.
Return type:list[frozenset]
get_maxcliques_percolation()[source]¶

The main method to find clusters based on maximal clique percolation.

The first step is to build temporary graph (percolation graph). Then the procedure finds all maximal cliques in the graph. Next, it looks for percolation between cliques. This method then remove any edges that connecting two vertices but has different clusters.

Returns:clusters – List of frozenset containing node identifier (node id in integer).
Return type:dict[frozenset]
class MaxCliquesPercolationWeighted(graph, edges_weight, nodes_id, k, threshold)[source]¶

Bases: pygraphc.clustering.MaxCliquesPercolation.MaxCliquesPercolation

This is a class for maximal clique percolation with edge weight [Liu2009].

Edge weight is evaluated using intensity threshold or the geometric mean for all edge weights in a maximal clique [Studiawan2016c]. We then remove the overlapping nodes where a node only follow the weighter neighboring cluster [Studiawan2016c].

References

[Liu2009]Guimei Liu, Limsoon Wong, and Hon Nian Chua. Complex discovery from weighted PPI networks. Bioinformatics, 25(15):1891-1897, 2009.
[Studiawan2016c](1, 2) H. Studiawan, C. Payne, F. Sohel, SSH log clustering using weighted maximal clique percolation (to be submitted).
_MaxCliquesPercolationWeighted__get_clusters()¶

Get maximal clique percolation as clusters with incremental cluster id.

Returns:clusters – Dictionary of list containing node identifier for each cluster found.
Return type:dict[list]
_MaxCliquesPercolationWeighted__get_neighbors_weight(node, neighbors)¶

Get all weight of neighboring cluster.

Parameters:
  • node (int) – Node identifier
  • neighbors (list[int]) – List of node identifier of intersection between two clusters
Returns:

weight – Sum of all edge weight from specific neighboring cluster.
Return type:

int
